tinfour.las

Enum LasGpsTimeType

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<LasGpsTimeType>
      • tinfour.las.LasGpsTimeType
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<LasGpsTimeType>

    public enum LasGpsTimeType
extends java.lang.Enum<LasGpsTimeType>
    Indicates which format was used to represent GPS time values associated with the sample points in an file.

    • Enum Constant Summary

      Enum Constants 
      Enum Constant and Description
      SatelliteTime
      Time value in seconds measured from the start of the epoch at midnight, Sunday morning, January 6, 1980 and adjusted by subtracting the offset 1.0e+9.
      WeekTime
      Time value in seconds measured from the start of the week at midnight Sunday morning UTC.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static long GPS_EPOCH_SECONDS
      Specifies the time in seconds for the GPS EPOCH which is defined as 1980-01-06 00:00:00 UTC.

    • Enum Constant Detail

      • WeekTime

        public static final LasGpsTimeType WeekTime
        Time value in seconds measured from the start of the week at midnight Sunday morning UTC.

      • SatelliteTime

        public static final LasGpsTimeType SatelliteTime
        Time value in seconds measured from the start of the epoch at midnight, Sunday morning, January 6, 1980 and adjusted by subtracting the offset 1.0e+9. This offset is used by the LAS format to reduce the magnitude of the time and preserve the precision of lower-order digits.

    • Field Detail

      • GPS_EPOCH_SECONDS

        public static final long GPS_EPOCH_SECONDS
        Specifies the time in seconds for the GPS EPOCH which is defined as 1980-01-06 00:00:00 UTC. Seconds are used rather than Java milliseconds to facilitate calculations of the GPS time value without losing precision.

        The GPS Epoch was computed using the following code 

         GregorianCalendar c=new GregorianCalendar(new SimpleTimeZone(0,"UTC"));
 c.clear();
 c.set(1980, 0, 6, 0, 0, 0);
 Date d = c.getTime();
 long t = c.getTimeInMillis();
        If you work with calendar, do not forget the call to clear. The Java calendar class is a truly awful implementation and one of its many shortcomings is that if you do not call clear it will populate the milliseconds element with the current system clock and the call to set() does not zero-out that field.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • transformGpsTimeToMillis

        public long transformGpsTimeToMillis(double lasGpsTime)
        Converts a LAS GPS time given from the representation specified by this enumeration state to a Java time in milliseconds from the EPOCH Jan 1, 1970. Note: This class does not yet account for GPS leap seconds. Further research is required to resolve this issue.
        Parameters:
        lasGpsTime - a valid LAS-formatted GPS Time in the same representation as this enumeration.
        Returns:
        a time in milliseconds

      • transformGpsTimeToDate

        public java.util.Date transformGpsTimeToDate(double lasGpsTime)
        Converts a LAS GPS time given from the representation specified by this enumeration to a valid Java Date instance.

        Note: This class does not yet account for GPS leap seconds. Further research is required to resolve this issue.

        Parameters:
        lasGpsTime - a valid LAS-formatted GPS Time in the same representation as this enumeration.
        Returns:
        a valid Date instance
